text:
This is probably a better place than General to drop this
I know I’m just missing something but my navbar keeps displaying as an unordered list instead of dropdowns, I don’t know what I missed. Help, please?

I’m an HS developer, and the themes I worked on were built by me, so I never had to use a child theme. I picked up a project that uses the Power Theme that has been edited on the front end for the last couple of months. I need some clarification. 1. When they update, will that affect the work they have done already? 2. Would creating a child theme affect the work they have already done? 3. Are there any files I should not pull into the child theme <@U03AKL6Q1B2>? Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Hi <@U064LSX4L9K>, happy to help
Thank you never used a child theme (HubSpot) so want to make sure I’m doing this correctly.
Since they don't have a child theme, when they install an update it will apply automatically to all assets that are using the marketplace theme
But it won’t reset the changes they made?
in the DnD editor or code changes?
DnD editor.

correct, no changes will happen to the content in the DnD editor - they will gain access to any new features, but it shouldn't cause any impact on content or live pages (unless it's a bug, which would be very rare)

So how I understand it basically everything I see in the CLI tool would be the theme and all changes on the front end are part of the database that it draws in. Would that be a correct way to picture it.?

If you create a child theme now, you would have to migrate all of the content over on the front end (swapping the templates) but the module IDs will still be associated with the marketplace version unless you change them on the page.

This is important to note with how creating customization in the child theme works, should you ever delete something.

In the child theme, nearly all of your changes can be made in the child.css and child.js, ideally you don't overwrite any of the theme CSS or JS files, instead you can add/extend/overwrite via these files.
They want me to edit the blog listing page would I just pull it into the child theme?

If you need to create a custom module - there are two routes:

1 - clone an existing module and keep the same name, this will overwrite it so only one version is available. No future updates would apply to this module

2 - clone the module and rename it - this will create a unique version and allow you to customize as much as needed, but still retain the original version should you need/want existing capabilities

For templates, it's the same - so yes, if you need to modify the blog listing page, you can clone that template to the child theme and overwrite directly (don't rename unless you want multiple versions)

The less you overwrite in the child theme the better, creating unique custom modules/templates is usually better because you're extending functionality.

If we release an update to a module you customized, you'd have to manually review the code to apply the update if you need/want it
Interesting I can see how this could become very complicated if not done correctly.
yes, it's possible
Most of the updates are for new features, but they also do an amazing job of keeping it updated for browser compatibility, so it's worth keeping it up to date

Ok let me backtrack for a moment something I didn’t understand “If you create a child theme now, you would have to migrate all of the content over on the front end (swapping the templates) but the module IDs will still be associated with the marketplace version unless you change them on the page.”
Do you mean they would need to redo what they have done?
“migrate all of the content”

it depends - a child theme has it's own unique theme settings, so it will copy what you have at the time it's created, but they are independent of each other. If you only want to customize the blog, there are easier ways than creating a child theme at this point
That is exactly what I was thinking.
Would it just be better to create a clone and make it independent.
no - I never recommend a clone, but you could create a child theme specifically for the blog and not move any of the website content over
they'll still be independent, but they'd both be able to receive updates
So create the child then pull it in to the child?
yes, create a child theme like "Power x Client Blog" and then use the "clone to child" option for the blog listing template
Ok so here is the kicker.

The blog listing page is being used for more of a knowledge base hub so if I do that then they wouldn’t have a blog listing page anymore at least not like the power theme so later if they wanted one they would have to clone it anyway correct.
Or could we pull it from the marketplace version?
You could just rename it and change the template in the settings
as long as it has a unique file name, they can retain access to both versions (custom and original)
the blog settings will let you choose any template in the portal configured as a listing page
It could even be completely unrelated to POWER if that's easier for the purposes of this KB Hub
So just trying to wrap my head around this. So clone it to the child then the name no longer matters unless I want it to receive updates?
kind of...

if the file in the child theme is the SAME as the marketplace, that file will overwrite the marketplace and loses access to updates

if the file in the child theme is UNIQUE from the marketplace, that file would also not be updated, but the original file still exists
in the second situation, the original file still gets updates and could still be used independently of your custom version

so if you clone blog-listing.html to the child theme and keep the name, you'll only have one option available in blog settings.

if you change the name to blog-kb-listing.html then you would see both options in the available templates for the blog settings
Ok so in my case I’m always very cautious so in most instances, I would want to give it a unique name. Would that be correct so the owners always have the originals?
yes, that's the best practice that I follow also
Ok starting to get it. Why do you suggest making a child of the blog seperately?
just so you don't have to move all of the website content to the child (manually swapping the template from one theme to the other)
Because the blog is kinda a separate entity.

You'll also have more flexibility - since they're using the blog as a KB Hub, you could customize modules, etc. that can be added via DnD or to the template without worrying about it showing on the website pages
It would also be easier to configure the header/footer - especially if they decide to add a regular blog down the road
So is that usually best practice to have separate child themes for the webpages vs blog listing?
no, just in this situation
if you were starting from scratch with nothing built, it would be very different
Because the child would reset the webpages?

the child won't impact the web pages at all, it just creates manual work if you want everything on the same theme

if you were starting from scratch, you could build everything from the same theme the first time around, and could configure everything accordingly.

I don't know how big the website is, but the process of swapping page templates is very tedious
Yea don’t want to do that.

You can also reach out directly at <mailto:power@maka-agency.com|power@maka-agency.com> if you have any questions, their support team can help with any questions/concerns that you have.

cc: <@UHDEVB0S1> <@ULP2AVB32> to loop them in on your question about child themes and custom dev
So just to double-check create a child and name it something around “kb-hub-listing” then just put the put the listing page in there.
yep, and then choose that from your blog settings
Perfect thanks so much for your help.
You're welcome! I hope you enjoy customizing the theme, it's a really fun, flexible theme to work with
